items.standfirst: A 27-year-old man will face court on the Gold Coast, charged with murder after allegedly stabbing a man known to him.
items.content: A 27-year-old man will face court on the Gold Coast, charged with murder after allegedly stabbing a man known to him.

items.title: Man charged with murder after man stabbed to death in Gold Coast unit block
items.standfirst: 9News understands the alleged offender had walked to a nearby construction site and told workers what unfolded before attempting to flee to Upper Coomera.
items.content: A man has been charged with murder after allegedly stabbing a man to death in a unit block on the Gold Coast yesterday.Members of the public called police to report the concerning behaviour of a man in Dutton Street, Coolangatta yesterday afternoon. 9News understands the alleged offender had walked to a nearby construction site and told workers what unfolded before attempting to flee to Upper Coomera.READ MORE: 'Kill crew' trio charged with murdering alleged drug syndicate member's wifeOfficers found the body of a 57-year-old Coolangatta man with stab wounds at a unit block on that street.A 27-year-old Coolangatta man was arrested in Upper Coomera just after 2pm (AEST).He has been charged with one count of murder and one count of unlawful use of a motor vehicle and is due to appear at Southport Magistrates Court today.READ MORE: Mum's plea after athletic daughter almost dies from 'cruel' disease Two separate crime scenes have been established, in Coolangatta and in Upper Coomera.The investigation is ongoing and anyone with information, CCTV or dashcam is urged to contact police. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

The stabbing occurred near the border.

The victim was known to the accused.

clusters.title: ‘Kill crew’ charged with murder of Sydney woman
clusters.neutral_headline: Kill Crew" Charged in Sydney Woman's Murder
bullet_summary: Reported by The Age, ABC News Australia, 9News

items.title: ‘Kill crew’ charged with murder of Sydney woman
items.standfirst: Thi Kim Tran, 45, was kidnapped in front of children, shot dead and her body dumped in a burning car.
items.content: Thi Kim Tran, 45, was kidnapped in front of children, shot dead and her body dumped in a burning car.

items.title: Police charge 'contracted kill crew' over brutal murder of Sydney woman
items.standfirst: Three men have been charged with murder after a Sydney woman was kidnapped and killed over her husband's drug debt earlier this year.
items.content: Three men have been charged with murder after a Sydney woman was kidnapped and killed over her husband's drug debt earlier this year.

items.title: Alleged 'kill crew' trio charged with kidnapping and murdering Sydney woman Thi Kim Tran
items.standfirst: They allegedly assaulted an eight-year-old boy with a baseball bat, before forcing the woman to strip naked on the street and get into an SUV.
items.content: Three men allegedly part of a "kill crew" sent to kill an organised criminal network member have been charged with kidnapping and murdering his wife in south-west Sydney.Thi Kim Tran, 45, was at her home in Bankstown about 10.30pm on April 17 when a group of men allegedly forced their way in and kidnapped her at gunpoint.They allegedly assaulted an eight-year-old boy with a baseball bat, putting him in a coma, before forcing the woman to strip naked on the street and forcing her into an SUV.READ MORE: 'Mind boggling': NBA coach and player charged over massive betting schemesA 15-year-old boy at the home was also taken to hospital for assessment.About an hour later, a car was found burning on Welfare Avenue in nearby Beverly Hills.Fire crews extinguished the blaze, but the car was destroyed and police found Tran dead inside.Police allege the woman was likely targeted due to her husband's involvement with a Victoria-based organised criminal network.The Anh Nguyen, 29, was charged in August with facilitating the alleged kidnapping and murder.Nguyen is not alleged to have killed Tran himself, but to have brought the three men who allegedly did to her home and facilitated it.READ MORE: With this handshake, King makes history in a 500-year firstREAD MORE: Tragic discovery in search for missing mumStrike Force Bushfield detectives yesterday arrested three men, aged 32, 20 and 21, allegedly part of a "kill crew" tasked with finding and killing Ms Tran's husband.Police claim the men murdered Tran when they couldn't find her husband.They were charged with murder, conspiring to murder, wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm, kidnapping in company and participating in a criminal group.No details were provided about when they would face court.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: Three men were charged with the murder of a Sydney woman.
The woman was kidnapped and killed.

The woman's body was dumped in a burning car.
An eight-year-old boy was assaulted.

clusters.title: LeBron unwittingly dragged into NBA gambling scandal; dozens arrested in probe tied to mafia
clusters.neutral_headline: NBA Coach, Player Charged in Gambling and Mafia Schemes
bullet_summary: More than 30 people have been charged in connection with schemes involving illegal sports betting and rigged poker games, authorities said
Reported by The Age, ABC News Australia, 9News

items.title: LeBron unwittingly dragged into NBA gambling scandal; dozens arrested in probe tied to mafia
items.standfirst: More than 30 people have been charged in connection with schemes involving illegal sports betting and rigged poker games, authorities said.
items.content: More than 30 people have been charged in connection with schemes involving illegal sports betting and rigged poker games, authorities said.

items.title: NBA stars and mafia figures arrested in illegal gambling sting
items.standfirst: Chauncey Billups, the coach of Portland, and Miami Heat guard Terry Rozier are among more than 30 people arrested in two cases alleging sprawling criminal schemes to rake in millions by rigging sports bets and poker games.
items.content: Chauncey Billups, the coach of Portland, and Miami Heat guard Terry Rozier are among more than 30 people arrested in two cases alleging sprawling criminal schemes to rake in millions by rigging sports bets and poker games.

items.title: NBA coach and player charged in betting and Mafia-backed poker schemes
items.standfirst: Authorities described one scheme as one "of the most brazen sports corruption schemes since online sports betting became widely legalised in the United States".
items.content: An NBA head coach and a player are among more than 30 people charged in connection with schemes involving illegal sports betting and rigged poker games backed by the Mafia, authorities say.Miami Heat guard Terry Rozier is accused of participating in an illegal sports betting scheme using private insider NBA information, officials said on Thursday (early Friday AEDT).Portland Trail Blazers head coach Chauncey Billups is charged in a separate indictment alleging a wide-ranging scheme to rig underground poker games that were backed by Mafia families, authorities said.READ MORE: With this handshake, King makes history in a 500-year firstThe indictments are related to two major cases, one involving sports betting and the second involving rigged poker games, US Attorney Joseph Nocella Jr said at a news conference with FBI Director Kash Patel.Patel said the "mind-boggling" scale of theft, fraud and robbery involved "tens of millions of dollars".In the first case, six defendants are accused of participating in an insider sports betting conspiracy that exploited confidential information about NBA athletes and teams, Nocella said, calling it "one of the most brazen sports corruption schemes since online sports betting became widely legalised in the United States".The second case involves 31 defendants in a nationwide scheme to rig illegal poker games, Nocella said. The defendants include former professional athletes accused of using technology to steal millions of dollars from victims in underground poker games in the New York area that were backed by Mafia families, he said.Athletes accused of leaving games earlyIn the sports betting scheme, players sometimes altered their performance or took themselves out of games early, New York Police Commissioner Jessica Tisch said.In one instance, Rozier, while playing for the Hornets, told others he was planning to leave the game early with a "supposed injury", allowing others to place wagers that raked in thousands of dollars, Tisch said.The indictment of Rozier and others says there are nine unnamed co-conspirators including a Florida resident who was an NBA player and an Oregon resident who was an NBA player from about 1997 to 2014 and an NBA coach since at least 2021, as well as a relative of Rozier.Rozier and other defendants "had access to private information known by NBA players or NBA coaches" that was likely to affect the outcome of games or players' performances and provided that information to other co-conspirators in exchange for either a flat fee or a share of betting profits, the indictment says.READ MORE: Tragic discovery in search for missing mumThe NBA had investigatedThe NBA, which had investigated Rozier previously, had no immediate comment.Rozier was in uniform as the Heat played the Magic in Orlando, Florida, in the season opener for both teams on Wednesday evening, though he did not play in the game.He was taken into custody in Orlando early Thursday morning. The team didn't immediately comment on the arrest.A message was left with Rozier's lawyer, Jim Trusty, on Thursday. Trusty previously told ESPN that Rozier was told that an initial investigation determined he did nothing wrong after he met with NBA and FBI officials in 2023, the sports network reported.A message seeking comment was left with Billups on Thursday morning.READ MORE: Iconic Aussie food company collapses owing millionsThe case was brought by the US attorney's office in Brooklyn that previously prosecuted ex-NBA player Jontay Porter. The former Toronto Raptors centre pleaded guilty to charges that he withdrew early from games, claiming illness or injury, so that those in the know could win big by betting on him to underperform expectations.Billups was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame last year. The five-time All-Star and three-time All-NBA point guard led the Detroit Pistons to their third league title in 2004 as NBA Finals MVP.Boston drafted the former Colorado star with the No.3 pick overall in 1997. The player known as Mr Big Shot also played for Toronto, Denver, Minnesota, the New York Knicks and the Los Angeles Clippers.Billups won the Joe Dumars Trophy, the NBA's sportsmanship award, in 2009 while playing for his hometown Denver Nuggets.The 49-year-old is in his fifth season as Portland's coach, compiling a 117-212 record. The Trail Blazers opened the season on Wednesday night at home with a 118-114 loss to Minnesota.A game involving Rozier that has been in question was played on March 23, 2023, a matchup between the Hornets and the New Orleans Pelicans.Rozier played the first nine minutes and 36 seconds of that game — and not only did not return that night, citing a foot issue, but did not play again that season.Charlotte had eight games remaining and was not in playoff contention, so it did not seem particularly unusual that Rozier was shut down for the season's final games.In that March 23 game, Rozier finished with five points, four rebounds and two assists in that opening period — a productive quarter but well below his usual total output for a full game.Posts still online from March 23, 2023, show that some bettors were furious with sportsbooks that evening when it became evident that Rozier was not going to return to the Charlotte-New Orleans game after the first quarter, with many turning to social media to say that something "shady" had gone on regarding the prop bets involving his stats for that night.A prop is a type of wager that allows gamblers to bet on whether a player will exceed a certain statistical number, such as whether the player will finish over or under a certain total of points, rebounds, assists and more.There are many different ways to get help and information about gambling. You can visit the National Gambling Helpline or call on 1800 858 858.

ai_summary: Authorities arrested over thirty people in connection with illegal sports betting schemes.
Chauncey Billups and Terry Rozier are among those arrested in the gambling probe.
The schemes allegedly involved rigging sports bets and poker games for millions.
One scheme was described as a brazen sports corruption case.
The investigation involved multiple mafia families and illegal poker games.

clusters.title: Award-winning journalist reveals 'intimidation' incident at home
clusters.neutral_headline: Journalist Reports Intimidation Incident at His Home
bullet_summary: P olice are reportedly investigating an incident at Nick McKenzie's home which involved an attack on his CCTV
Gold Walkley winner Nick McKenzie speaks to Today after an incident at his home he said was attempted "intimidation"

items.title: Award-winning journalist reveals 'intimidation' incident at home
items.standfirst: P olice are reportedly investigating an incident at Nick McKenzie's home which involved an attack on his CCTV.
items.content: A ward-winning investigative journalist Nick McKenzie has spoken out after his home was reportedly targeted in an apparent intimidation incident, saying he has "strong suspicions" about who was behind it.Victoria Police are investigating the incident, according to The Age, which took place earlier this month.McKenzie told Today the incident was "designed to intimidate" him and involved an attack on his home's CCTV system.READ MORE: Remains of 1990 teen murder victim sought in NSW river "An offender entering or surveilling the property, getting onto the roof and doing certain things in a manner designed not just to mess with the system and the home, but to leave a message," he said.The Gold Walkley winner said he had "full confidence" in the police investigation into the event. "As an investigative reporter, you do lots of work, annoying lots of people. That's the job," he said. He speculated that the incident might be linked to a recent investigation which would be published as a major series this weekend in Nine newspapers and on 60 Minutes.Nine is the owner of this website. McKenzie said the incident wouldn't stop his work"As soon as the press is silenced, then we no longer have a free press," he said.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.
